Graphical abstract The defect chemistry of doped-ceria is vital but tangled for sustainable conversion of biomass resources. In this work, a group of Zr-doped CeO2 solid solutions were prepared and the defect chemistry in CeZr x O y (0.02 ≤ x ≤ 5) catalyst was elucidated over the oxidative coupling of lignin-based aniline and benzyl alcohol. Varying the Zr molar fraction enabled to successfully adjust the defect sites of catalysts and further influence their catalytic performances. In addition, the optimal CeZr1O y catalyst exhibited a flexible temperature adaptability, wide substrate scope and superior reusability. Various characterizations, kinetic investigations, controlled experiments, DFT calculations and in situ DRIFT-IR technique were used to unravel the roles of Ce3+ and oxygen defects and the reaction mechanism. It was disclosed that Zr-doped defects can obviously increase surface Ce3+ cations, oxygen species (peroxide and superoxide anions) and oxygen vacancies. These coordinatively unsaturated sites were shown to play critical roles in absorbing and activating substrates hence can accelerate the formation rate of bio-based imines. Keywords Bio-based imine Zr doping Solid solution Doped defects Oxygen vacancy Green synthesis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Conversion of biomass resources into sustainable chemicals and fuels is a major task of current catalysis. Imines stand as a class of important nitrogen-containing organic intermediates. The downstream transformations of reactive C=N bond in an imine can lend itself to wide applications in agrochemical, pharmaceutical and polymer industries [1]. In recent years, the direct oxidative coupling of amines with alcohols for imine productions is becoming a promising approach [2]. Moreover, the mature and scaled synthesis of lignin-based aniline and benzyl alcohol has been realized via biorefining [3]. In the upgrading routes for lignin, typical model compounds such as phenol, diphenyl ether, benzaldehyde, acetophenone and benzyl alcohol can be easily acquired by depolymerization of lignin. In the meantime, aniline can be obtained by cross-coupling reaction using lignin-derived phenol or ether as substrate. Thereby, catalytic oxidative coupling of aniline and benzyl alcohol to bio-based imine is well in the line of sustainable chemistry (Scheme S1), offering novel research ideas for further expanding the boundaries of biomass refining systems involving lignin amination chemistry. This atom-economic reaction would only yield water as byproduct in theory and might adapt a wide substrate scope. The oxidative coupling reaction takes advantages of a faster response and a lower temperature. However, even the model reaction between aniline and benzyl alcohol is encountered with some problems in fundamental research. Specifically, selective activation of the C−OH bond and stabilization of the C=N bond under mild reaction conditions remain difficult [4,5]. In this context, transition-metal oxides as inexpensive heterogeneous catalysts are highly favorable to the oxidative coupling of aniline and benzyl alcohol, only by smartly using their surface defects towards alcohol-O2 activation. As a classic rare-earth oxide, the fluorite-type ceria (CeO2) has been widely used to catalyze oxidation reactions by taking advantages of its unique redox property and superior oxygen storage-diffusion ability [6]. As expected, ceria catalysts are studied for imine synthesis from the oxidative coupling of aniline and benzyl alcohol [7–12]. Tamura et al. first disclosed that the redox property of CeO2 enabled imine formation at only 30 °C with a moderate yield of 75% in air atmosphere [7]. The follow-up studies were devoted to boosting redox ability of CeO2 by modulating the crystal facet, morphology and surface area [8–10]. Particularly, defect-enriched CeO2 showed obviously higher productivity of benzylideneaniline [11,12]. Defective structures are commonly present in solid materials. The so-called point defects reflected by oxygen defects have been largely used in heterogeneous oxidation catalysis [13]. Doping is one of effective ways to regulate the catalyst defects. As is known to all, the isomorphic substitution of Ce4+ ions inside CeO2 lattices by metal dopant with an odd charge would usually give rise to lattice defects [14]. Besides, the different radii between the doped ions and Ce4+ ions enable an expansion or contraction of the lattice of solid solution. These would affect the stress of pristine ceria-lattice and the amount of defects. Hence, transition metals can be ideal for CeO2 doping to enhance oxygen defects which benefit the oxidative coupling of amines and alcohols. However, this strategy can be scarcely reported in the literature. Previously, Zhang et al. showed that the Ce-Ni redox system and interaction between the two metals allowed controlling the proportions of Ce3+ ions and oxygen vacancies of a CeNi x O y solid solution [15]. The optimal CeNi0.3O y catalyst can reach 99% yield of imine at 100 °C after 26 h. Following that, Qin et al. adopted an amorphous Fe2O3 to modify CeO2, which greatly improved the [O] transfer cycle of Ce4+/Ce3+ pair and thus enhanced redox and amphoteric properties of the catalysts [16]. 97% yield of imine was obtained over the Fe8Ce2-100 catalyst at 60 °C after 9 h. Obviously, the defect chemistry of doped-CeO2 is very important but remains unclear. Unfortunately, neither of them can unravel modulation and catalysis of the doped defects in ceria-based solid solutions for oxidative coupling of amines and alcohols. Herein, this work aims to deeply clarify the defect chemistry of a Zr-doped CeO2 solid solution catalyst for imine synthesis via oxidative coupling of aniline as well as other amines with benzyl alcohol under air atmosphere. It is found that manipulating the Zr molar fraction can successfully adjust the defect sites and further affect the catalytic performances. XRD, HR-TEM, N2 physisorption, Raman, EPR, H2-TPR and XPS are used to systematically investigate the formation, type and function of doped defects in the CeZr x O y catalysts. In addition, kinetic investigations, controlled experiments (i.e., by using different atmospheres, scavengers and annealing) and DFT calculations are rationally conducted to specifically disclose the role of oxygen defects. Finally, time-resolved in situ DRIFT-IR is adopted to get insights into the structure–activity relationship and reaction mechanism. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and reagents Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (99.5%), ZrO(NO3)2⋅xH2O (99.9%), poly (ethylene glycol)-block-poly (propylene glycol)-block-poly (ethylene glycol) (P123, average Mn: 5800) were purchased from Alfa Aesar. Ammonia solution (AR, 28%), methanol (99.5%) and toluene (AR) were obtained from Aladdin®. Aniline (>99%), benzyl alcohol (99%), benzaldehyde (99%) and N-benzylideneaniline (99%) were purchased from Acros Organics. The standard imine compounds for substrate-scope investigation were from commercial and/or lab-made sources. 2.2 Synthesis of CeZr x O y solid solutions The CeZr x O y catalysts were synthesized by a template-induced and step-precipitation method. Typically, P123 (n (P123/Ce) = 0.02) was dissolved in 100 mL of distilled water. Then, 5 mmol of cerium salt was added and dissolved, followed by precipitation with ammonia till pH = 9. The suspension was stirred for 30 min and subsequently zirconium salt was added (n (Zr/Ce) = 0, 0.02, 0.1, 0.3, 0.5, 1, 2 and 5) and precipitated again by ammonia till pH = 9. Afterwards, the suspension was stirred at 25 °C for 12 h and at 90 °C for 3 h under a reflux condenser. The resultant solids were collected by filtration and washed with excess distilled water till the filtrate became neutral. In the end, the catalysts were dried at 110 °C for 12 h and calcined at 400 °C under an air flow for 4 h. 2.3 Material characterizations Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed on a Rigaku TTR Ⅲ diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation and a beam voltage of 40 kV. Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) was carried out on an Agilent 7500a apparatus. N2 physisorption was conducted at 77 K on a V-Sorb 4800 specific surface area and pore size analyzer from Chinainstru & Quantumtech (Hefei) Co., Ltd. BET and BJH models were employed for calculation. Temperature-programed reduction of hydrogen (H2-TPR) was done on a Micromeritics Autochem II chemisorption analyzer. The solids were pretreated with a volumetric 5% H2−95% Ar mixed gas for 30 min, and then the temperature was raised to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1. Low-temperature electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) was conducted at 77 K on an A300 Bruker ERP spectrometer with X-band frequency of 9.4 GHz under a 100 kHz field modulation frequency and 1.0 G standard modulation amplitude. The quantitative calculation was based on the DPPH standard. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out on a Thermo Fisher Scientific K-Alpha+ apparatus equipped with a mono Al Kα radiation. The binding energy shift due to surface charging was adjusted to the standard of C 1s line at 284.6 eV. Time resolved in situ reaction was monitored by diffuse reflectance Fourier transform infrared (DRIFT-IR) spectrometry on a Thermo Scientific Nicolet-iS50 FT-IR apparatus armed with a MCT detector. The powdery CeZr1O y catalyst was added to the cell and 5 μL of different substrates (i.e., benzyl alcohol, aniline, benzaldehyde and imine) was then added respectively. Thus the background spectra of catalyst and catalyst-substrate were recorded. The controlled experiments were conducted to study the reaction path and mechanism. i) Aniline (5 μL) and benzyl alcohol (7.5 μL) and ii) benzyl alcohol (5 μL) reacted over the CeZr1O y catalyst (50 mg) under air atmosphere. The FT-IR spectrum was collected every one minute up to 60 min. 2.4 Catalytic reaction The oxidative coupling of aniline, as well as different primary amines, with benzyl alcohol was carried out on a WP-TEC-1020HC parallel reactor manufactured by WATTCASTM (Fig. S1). Typically, 0.5 mmol of aniline, 0.75 mmol of benzyl alcohol and 50 mg of CeZr x O y catalyst were mixed by 5 mL of toluene. Then the reaction mixture was stirred under air atmosphere at 80 °C for 8 h. The stirring speed of 900 rpm was verified to eliminate both internal and external diffusion limitations. The reaction was quenched by an ice water and the clear liquid after filtration was analyzed on a Thermo Scientific TRACE 1310 GC armed with a TR-5 column and a FID detector. The external standard method was used to quantify the initial reaction rate and conversion of aniline, the selectivity and yield of imine on the basis of carbon balance (see the Supplementary material). Notably, the carbon balance was monitored for each reaction and the data were found almost 100%. For recycling test, the used and separated catalyst was thoroughly washed with ethanol and water, and then dried at 110 °C followed by a calcining at 400 °C for 4 h before next use. 2.5 Density function theory calculation First principles calculations were carried out in the framework of density function theory (DFT) by using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [17]. These were performed within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA), employing the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) formulation [18]. The ionic cores were described with the projected augmented wave (PAW) potentials [19,20], and the valence electrons were considered using a plane wave basis set with a kinetic energy cutoff of 450 eV. Self-consistent calculations employed a convergence energy threshold of 10–5 eV. Equilibrium geometries and lattice constants were optimized, with a maximum stress of 0.02 eV Å−1 applied to each atom. The CeO2 (111) and Zr-CeO2-Vö (111) surfaces were modeled using the 2 × 2 supercell slab models, containing six atomic layers slabs. The bottom four layers were constrained at the optimized bulk position, and the top two layers with the adsorbates were allowed to relax. A 17 Å vacuum layer was added to the surface to eliminate the interactions from the top (15 Å) and slab (2 Å) supercells. Weak interaction was addressed using the DFT + D3 method, employing Grimme’s empirical correction scheme [21,22]. A 2 × 2 × 1 Gamma k-point mesh was employed in the calculation of bulk properties for all the models. Adsorption energy (E ads) was defined by the equation: E ads = E slab+m-E slab-E m. Where E slab is the energy of a clean surface, E m is the energy of O2 or benzyl alcohol molecule, and E slab+m is the total energy of surface and O2 or benzyl alcohol adsorbed on it. To account for strong correlation effects of the transition metal in the structure, structural optimizations incorporated the spin-dependent GGA plus Hubbard correction U method, with an effective Ueff parameter set to 5.0 eV for the Ce atom. No U correction was used for Zr d-states. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Constructing Zr-doped CeO2 solid solution catalyst for oxidative coupling reaction As shown in Fig. 1 A, C, all the CeZr x O y (0.02 ≤ x ≤ 5) catalysts only display the characteristic patterns of a cubic CeO2 phase [12]. The complete planes of CeO2 can be well observed when the Zr/Ce ratio ≤ 1. However, by further increasing the ratio over 1, the peaks become broader and less intense. As shown in Fig. 1B, the (111) plane of CeO2 slightly shifts to higher 2θ as the Zr/Ce ratio continuously grows. Meanwhile, doping Zr to CeO2 can result in shrinkage of the grain sizes of CeZr x O y catalysts from 12.4 nm down to 9.6 nm (Table 1 ). These results can be attributed to the isomorphic substitution of Ce cations by Zr cations inside a cubic CeO2 lattice (Fig. 1D) [23], leading to formation of the doped Ce-Zr-O solid solutions and contracted CeO2 crystals (i.e., d (Zr4+, 0.84 Å) < d (Ce4+, 0.97 Å)). As observed in HR-TEM image (Fig. 1E), the representative CeZr1O y catalyst shows vivid lattice fringes with interplanar distances of 0.304 nm and 0.267 nm, respectively. These values are smaller than the d spacing (i.e., 0.310 nm and 0.271 nm) of the (111) and (200) planes of a cubic CeO2 [24]. The decreased values can verify the crystal shrinkage and further imply the crystal defects of CeZr1O y solid. Besides, the SAED pattern can be assigned to the diffraction spots of the (111), (200), (220) and (311) planes of a CeZr1O y crystal (Fig. 1F) [25], in good agreement with the XRD pattern. In addition, ICP-MS analyses disclose that the bulk compositions of CeZr x O y catalysts well obey with the theoretical Zr/Ce ratios (Table 1). N2 physisorption was adopted to analyze the microstructure of Zr-doped CeO2. As shown in Fig. S2A, the prepared CeZr x O y catalysts all exhibit a distinctive type-Ⅳ isothermal profile and a typical H2 hysteresis loop, which indicates a mesoporous structure [26,27]. The pore size distribution can further confirm the fairly uniform mesopores inside the solids (Fig. S2B). As listed in Table 1, the specific surface areas of CeZr x O y catalysts obviously increase from 95 to 138 m2 g−1 and then decrease to 114 m2 g−1 with doping Zr, and the largest value is obtained on the CeZr1O y catalyst. As the Zr/Ce ratio grows, the pore size first increases and then decreases, which is well reflected by the shift of desorption platform. These variations can be caused by the continuous lattice distortions generated from Zr doping. The more crystal defects may induce the higher specific surface area and pore volume [28]. Thereby, the representative CeZr1O y catalyst could provide more active sites beneficial to effective transportation, adsorption and reaction of substrates on the solid surface. The oxidative coupling of aniline and benzyl alcohol was used as the model reaction for catalytic synthesis of bio-based imine. Firstly, ZrO2 alone is verified to be catalytically inactive for this reaction. As displayed in Fig. 2 a, the bare CeO2 catalyst can afford a low conversion of aniline (41%) but an excellent selectivity of benzylideneaniline (100%), showing an initial reaction rate of 0.51 mmol gcatal. −1 h−1 for aniline. By doping a trace of Zr into CeO2, the CeZr0.02O y catalyst already reaches 62% conversion and exhibits a high r initial of 0.80 mmol gcatal. −1 h−1 with the same product selectivity. The continuous increase of Zr content enables a rapid rise of catalytic activity and the optimal r initial of 1.52 mmol gcatal. −1 h−1 attained over the CeZr1O y catalyst. However, the r initial gradually declines to 1.15 mmol gcatal. −1 h−1 as the Zr/Ce ratio further grows to 5. The conversion of aniline also presents a rise-and-fall trend over the series of CeZr x O y catalysts and CeZr1O y achieves the best value of 97% (vs. 41% over CeO2) at 80 °C after 8 h (Fig. 2a). Obviously, Zr doping has no effect on the selectivity of products. All the series of CeZr x O y catalysts show an excellent selectivity of benzylideneaniline (100%). These results demonstrate that doping Zr to CeO2 allows significantly boosting the pristine activity of a fluorite-ceria catalyst. Furthermore, the Zr/Ce molar ratio can directly control the activity of the CeZr x O y catalysts. Afterwards, the apparent activation energies (E a) of oxidative coupling of aniline and benzyl alcohol over some typical CeZr x O y catalysts were measured and compared. The linear kinetic profiles are obtained during the initial reaction stage of aniline over the CeZr0.02O y , CeZr1O y and CeZr5O y catalysts (Fig. S3a−c). This is the characteristic of a pseudo first-order reaction with respect to aniline. The optimal CeZr1Oy catalyst exhibits different rate constants of aniline at 60, 70 and 80 °C. As expected, the highest k of 5.37 × 10−5 s−1 is obtained at 80 °C. Hence, a valid Arrhenius law can be used for calculating E a by numerical regression (Table S1). As expected, the optimal CeZr1O y catalyst shows a lowest E a of 40 kJ mol−1, followed by CeZr5O y (47 kJ mol−1) and CeZr0.02O y (51 kJ mol−1), in consistence with their catalytic activity. As a result, the CeZr1O y catalyst allows accelerating the initial conversion rate by offering a suitable path with a low energy barrier. Following that, the influence of reactant composition (i.e., molar ratio of aniline to benzyl alcohol) and reaction time was investigated over the optimal CeZr1O y catalyst. As plotted in Fig. 2c, different r initial of aniline are obtained by changing the reactant composition. However, this parameter has no effect on selectivity of imine. A volcano-like trend can be plotted and the highest r initial of aniline is detected when the molar ratio is of 0.66 (i.e., aniline: 0.5 mmol, benzyl alcohol: 0.75 mmol). This optimized ratio is thereby used all through the work. The equivalent reactants lead to a lowered r initial of 1.34 mmol gcatal. −1 h−1. During the variation of reactant composition, conversion of benzyl alcohol and selectivity of benzaldehyde were also calculated, which allowed understanding the formation and transformation of benzaldehyde intermediate. As reported in Fig. 2c, oxidation of benzyl alcohol also shows the similar trend of aniline conversion, which is delayed by low aniline concentration. 90% conversion of benzyl alcohol is attained at a ratio of 1.5 (i.e., aniline: 1.13 mmol, benzyl alcohol: 0.75 mmol). Selectivity of benzaldehyde continuously declines from 10% to zero with increasing aniline concentration, because the accumulated benzaldehyde at lower conversion of benzyl alcohol can be gradually reacted with the growing aniline. It is clear that an excessive aniline or benzyl alcohol would eventually retard the transformation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde [15], even though the catalyst can still drive the condensation of benzaldehyde with aniline. As observed during the time-course experiments (Fig. 2d), the CeZr1O y catalyst can completely convert aniline into benzylideneaniline in the presence of benzyl alcohol. This catalyst exhibits a fast response at 60 °C (r initial = 0.74 mmol gcatal. −1 h−1) and 80 °C (r initial = 1.52 mmol gcatal. −1 h−1). Conversions of aniline and yields of imine almost lineally increase within 4 h and 8 h, reaching 76% and 66% respectively. And the maximum yields of imine are achieved after 9 h (100%) and 16 h (97%), respectively. At 30 °C the CeZr1O y catalyst shows a very slow response (r initial = 0.08 mmol gcatal. −1 h−1) and performs a kinetic-controlled behavior within 48 h. Afterwards, the best CeZr1O y catalyst was evaluated at lower temperatures (Table 2 ). Though it shows a high imine yield of 97% at 80 °C after 8 h, this catalyst can also reach the same yield at 60 °C after 16 h. It may even perform a moderate yield of imine (40%) at as low as 30 °C using 48 h. In addition, this catalyst can work effectively with a concentrated aniline-toluene solution. For instance, a gram-scaled benzylideneaniline (1.78 g) is synthesized with an excellent yield of 98% at 80 °C after 24 h. Thereby, the optimal CeZr1O y catalyst can function under mild reaction conditions and shows potential for commercial imine synthesis. 3.2 Clarifying the doped defects and redox property of CeZr x O y catalysts Raman spectroscopy as a sensitive technique was used to monitor surface defects of a ceria-based catalyst. As shown in Fig. 3 A, the representative CeO2, CeZr0.02O y , CeZr1O y and CeZr5O y catalysts all display a strong F2g band at ca. 460 cm−1, which is characteristic of the fluorite phase of ceria nanocrystals [29]. Besides, weak bands at ca. 260 cm−1 due to nanostructured ceria are also observed [23]. Further inspection reveals that the F2g band of the optimal CeZr1O y catalyst becomes stronger and simultaneously shifts to the lowest frequency in comparison with other ceria-based catalysts. This phenomenon can be attributed to the presence of higher lattice distortion and oxygen vacancies (Vö) associated with Ce3+ ions in ceria [23]. Notably, the local vibration of Vö in Ce3+−Vö complexes shown by a small band at ca. 600 cm−1 is clearly observed on CeZr1O y [12,23]. Therefore, Raman results disclose the modification of lattice structure and the formation of doped defects for CeO2 by Zr doping. It is well known that the lattice defects can obviously affect the electronic structure of a solid. Hence EPR as a powerful technique was further used to probe Vö sites in the CeZr x O y catalysts. As shown in Fig. 3B, C, a free electron factor (g) of 2.003 and a signal at 3515 G are recorded, which directly confirms the presence of Vö originated from CeO2 in the CeZr x O y catalysts [12]. Moreover, the quantitative data reveal that CeZr x O y exhibit higher concentrations of Vö than CeO2 alone. Obviously, doping a small amount of Zr can induce a higher concentration of Vö on CeZr0.02O y (3.8 × 1017 spins g−1) compared to CeO2 (2.4 × 1017 spins g−1). Particularly, the best CeZr1O y catalyst displays the highest Vö of 5.0 × 1017 spins g−1. These results demonstrate that much more defective oxygen species are created in Zr-doped CeO2 solid solution. H2-TPR was performed to investigate the redox properties of CeZr x O y catalysts. As shown in Fig. 3D, all the catalysts present two reduction bands at around 470 °C and 750 °C, which correspond to the typical reduction of surface (Peak I, II) and bulk (Peak III) Ce4+ to Ce3+ [30], respectively. Interestingly, a new and intense reduction band (Peak I) is observed for CeZr x O y at much lower temperature of ca. 370 °C. This unique behavior can be also attributed to the reduction of surface Ce4+ to Ce3+ but stimulated by surface Vö [31], being an index of the surface defect sites on CeZr x O y . Inserting Zr cations to CeO2 lattice induces more Vö sites and doped defects on CeZr x O y surface, leading to the enhanced reduction of Ce4+ ions. As expected, the lowest reduction temperature is obtained on the optimal CeZr1O y catalyst. The total consumption of H2 is linearly correlated with the molar fraction of Ce inside CeZr x O y (Fig. S4). This shows that H2 is consumed to reduce Ce−O pairs in the CeZr x O y catalysts. Moreover, the quantitative analysis reveals the highest proportion of surface defects (Fig. S4) on the optimal CeZr1O y catalyst, which presents an enhanced redox ability and oxygen mobility. XPS was thereafter used to study surface composition and valence state of the CeZr x O y catalysts. Firstly, the measured surface Zr/Ce molar ratios seem lower than the bulk ones (Table 1). This phenomenon indicates a surface segregation of Ce atoms out of the CeZr x O y solid solutions due to the enhanced redox property of ceria (Fig. 3D). Then, the core-level spectra verify the co-presence of Ce3+ and Ce4+ ions (Fig. 3E) as well as typical Zr4+ (not shown) on surface. The binding energies (BEs) at 884.6 and 903.0 eV within three spin–orbit doublets of Ce 3d 5/2−3d 3/2 are assigned to Ce3+ ions [12], while the other peaks are ascribed to Ce4+ ions [12]. As the Zr content rises, BE of Ce cations decreases and that of Zr cations increases (Table S2), which indicates the strong interaction between Ce and Zr species due to an electron transfer. It has been reported that the electron-rich Ce cations present a lowered coordination number thus can be more conducive to adsorbing substrates [32]. Regarding the O 1s spectrum, two peaks can be resolved (Fig. 3F). Typical Olatt. species (O2−) in the Ce-Zr-O solid solutions and defective Osurf. species (O2 − and O− ions) related to reactive Vö are observed [33]. Compared to ceria, CeZr x O y all exhibit higher BEs for oxygen species (Table S3). The Olatt. species with a higher BE can be explained by the lattice distortion of Zr-doped CeO2 [34]. Similarly, the increased BE for Osurf. species has been also interpreted by the formation of a solid solution [35]. Furthermore, the quantitative analyses reveal that the proportions of unsaturated Ce3+ and Osurf. species show a rise-and-fall trend with increasing the Zr content (Table S2, S3). Even a small amount of Zr already enables obvious rise of those unsaturated species, and the highest values are found on the optimal CeZr1O y catalyst (i.e., Ce3+: 35.9% and Osurf.: 45.5%). It is well known that reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ is accompanied by formation of Vö which can sequentially transfer O2 into Osurf. species [12]. Therefore, the surface concentrations of Ce3+ and Osurf. can directly decide the amount of Ce3+−Vö active sites. 3.3 Structure-activity relationship and reaction mechanism upon defect chemistry Some controlled experiments were rationally designed to unravel the role of oxygen defects in catalytic performances. Firstly, the CeZr1O y catalyst was evaluated under either an inert or an oxidative atmosphere (Fig. 4 a). It is found in a continuous reaction that the oxidative coupling can proceed in the presence of Ar. Nonetheless, the reaction already stops after 3 h and conversion of aniline stabilizes at ca. 8%. When air is switched to the reactor, the reaction can be initiated again and conversion of aniline rapidly rises to 25% in 1 h. In this case, 99% conversion can be still achieved after 12 h. Moreover, the linear kinetic profiles of aniline conversion can be plotted for oxidative coupling of aniline and benzyl alcohol when the atmosphere is switched from Ar to air (Fig. 4b), which indicates that both reactions can obey the first-order kinetics with respect to aniline. However, a much lower rate constant of aniline (9.93 × 10−6 s−1) is measured in Ar compared to that (5.32 × 10−5 s−1) obtained later in air. Notably, nearly the same rate constant can be calculated directly in air over the CeZr1O y catalyst at 80 °C (Fig. S3b). This phenomenon illustrates that the intrinsic but limited reactive oxygen species in the CeZr1O y catalyst can drive the reaction in an inert gas. But free O2 is needed to supplement reactive oxygen via adsorption and activation and thus makes the reaction proceed. Then, the scavenger experiment was used to distinguish the reactive oxygen species and disclose the role of defective Osurf. species (Fig. 4c). p-Benzoquinone (PBQ) is well accepted as a scavenger of O2 − species [36]. Adding PBQ to the reaction mixture can result in a serious decline of catalytic activity of CeZr1O y . The added amount of PBQ is found to sharply inhibit conversion of aniline, and only ca. 1% conversion can be seen by using 5 mg of PBQ. Therefore, defective Osurf. can be verified as the reactive species. In the literature, Osurf. species (O2 − and O− ions) acted as highly active electrophilic radicals which can trigger dehydrogenation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde [37]. Finally, the CeZr1O y catalyst was thermal-treated with high-purity O2 for 2 h, in order to eliminate Vö. The Vö defects from surface to bulk may be gradually filled up by O2 with a heat treatment [38]. As shown in Fig. 4d, conversion of aniline significantly declines over the O2-treated catalyst under air. And the catalytic activity is observed to drop continuously and quickly with increasing the treatment temperature from 400 °C to 600 °C. These results clearly demonstrate that Vö defects enable to adsorb and activate O2 to generate Osurf. species for catalytic reaction and the concentration of Vö is vital. On the contrary, the O2-treated CeZr1O y catalyst shows relatively similar conversion of aniline under Ar. The partially eliminated Vö defects cannot give rise to an obvious decrease in catalytic activity. This phenomenon confirms again defective Osurf. species in CeZr1O y to be reactive and the consumption of Osurf. would not regenerate Vö. As the lowered Vö can reduce the concentration of Osurf. species, the treated CeZr1O y catalyst may exhibit a minor decrease in activity. Interestingly, H2 reduction (550 °C) of the O2-treated (500 °C) CeZr1O y catalyst cannot further boost its catalytic activity. In fact, very similar conversions of aniline are obtained (29% vs. 27%). This indicates that occupation and regeneration of Vö are irreversible through a redox treatment. Furthermore, H2-TPR profiles confirm the absence of low-temperature reduction band (Peak I) with O2 treatment at 500 °C and even after H2 reduction at 550 °C (Fig. S5). Notably, this peak is originated from reduction of surface Ce4+ to Ce3+ stimulated by surface Vö over the fresh CeZr x O y catalysts (Fig. 3D). Furthermore, DFT calculations illustrate an enhanced adsorption and activation of O2 on Vö at the (111) plane of Zr-doped CeO2 (Fig. S6). In contrast, O2 cannot considerably adsorb on the ideal CeO2 (111) surface (see detailed results in the Supplementary material) [39]. Based on the above results, the structure–activity relationship upon defect chemistry can be discussed. The defective sites are presented in the forms of Osurf. species, surface Ce3+ ions and Vö. The concentration of Vö is directly measured by low-temperature EPR (Fig. 3c), while those of Osurf. and Ce3+ are calculated from XPS fitting (Table S2, S3). Besides, the specific surface area may also reflect the crystal defects closely associated with reactive sites. Thereby the quantitative correlation is established between the initial reaction rate of aniline (mmol gcatal. −1 h−1) and productivity of benzylideneaniline (mmol gcatal. −1 h−1) and the concentration of defect sites and specific surface area. As plotted in Fig. 5 , r initial and prod. are disclosed to directly relate to the concentrations of reactive Osurf. species, surface unsaturated Ce3+ ions and Vö, as well as S BET. In other words, the intrinsic catalytic activity and efficiency of a CeZr x O y catalyst is revealed to originate from its defect structure. As previously demonstrated, the defective Osurf. species are essential and reactive to trigger oxidation of benzyl alcohol, and simultaneously the unsaturated Ce3+−Vö defects adsorb and activate O2 molecules to Osurf. species. Besides, the larger surface area could probably provide more reactive defect sites. Hence the optimal CeZr1O y catalyst with the highest concentrations of surface Osurf. species (45.5%), Ce3+ ions (35.9%) and Vö (5.0 × 1017 spins g−1) and the largest surface area (138 m2 g−1) enables the best catalytic activity in oxidative coupling of aniline and benzyl alcohol. Afterwards, the reaction path was monitored by time-resolved in situ DRIFT-IR spectroscopy. As shown in Fig. 6 a, a broad band centered at ca. 3400 cm−1 due to −OH groups in water molecules is observed over the CeZr1O y catalyst. The signals intensify with progress of reaction. This proves in situ formation of water from oxidative coupling of aniline and benzyl alcohol. As shown in Fig. 6b, the adsorption peaks of benzyl alcohol (i.e., δ O−H mode at ca. 1456 cm−1 and ν C=C mode at ca. 1500 cm−1) and aniline (i.e., δ N−H mode at ca. 1605 cm−1) are well recorded [40]. The intensity of adsorptions first increases and then decreases after 9 min, and finally stabilizes after 30 min. Importantly, several new peaks at 1700 cm−1 and 1585 cm−1 are first observed at 3 min, which can be assignable to C=O stretching vibration and benzene-ring skeleton vibration of benzaldehyde [40], respectively. Immediately, another new peak at 1625 cm−1 is observed at 4 min which can be ascribed to C=N stretching vibration of imine [40]. These peaks are well identical to the standard spectra of substrates (Fig. S7). It is clear to see that benzaldehyde signal (ν C=O mode) first increases and then decreases, while imine signal (ν C=N mode) increases continuously with the progress of reaction. This implies benzaldehyde as an intermediate. Therefore, aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde is considered to be the first step, and then benzaldehyde immediately condenses with aniline to form imine. Following that, the oxidation of benzyl alcohol was also in situ monitored. As shown in Fig. S8, benzyl alcohol firstly adsorbs on the CeZr1O y and CeO2 catalyst and then can be oxidized. Similarly, the water peak emerges and intensifies during the oxidation process. In the absence of aniline, the oxidation rate of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde obviously becomes slower, and the formation of benzaldehyde is observed after a longer time of 10 min over the CeZr1O y catalyst (Fig. 7 a). On the contrast, it takes 20 min to observe the formation of benzaldehyde on the CeO2 catalyst, and the intensity of C=O band obviously decreases at 60 min (Fig. 7c). This implies that aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol can be the rate-determining step for oxidative coupling of aniline and benzyl alcohol. This step can be promoted with the presence of aniline. That is because the weak basicity of aniline can facilitate the dehydrogenation of benzyl alcohol and thus accelerate the oxidation rate [41]. The CeZr1Oy catalyst can more effectively adsorb and activate benzyl alcohol to accelerate the rate-determining step. Notably, a band at ca. 1076 cm−1 due to ν C−OH mode of benzyl alcohol shifts to a higher frequency (Fig. 7b, d) [40], and a higher intensity band is observed on the CeZr1O y catalyst. This is the direct spectroscopic evidence of the formation of alkoxide intermediate. Usually alkoxide formation by an alcohol adsorption on metal sites can lead to a blue shift of ν C−O mode of the corresponding free alcohol [42,43]. Benzyl alcohol can be more effectively adsorbed on the electron-rich Ce3+ sites in a lowered coordination number via formation of an alkoxide intermediate. As illustrated in Fig. 7e, DFT calculations confirm that the adsorption of benzyl alcohol on Zr-CeO2-Vö (E ads: −2.274 eV) is significantly stronger than that on the ideal CeO2 (111) surface (E ads: −1.079 eV). This implies that the coordinatively unsaturated Ce3+ sites adjacent to Vö have stronger adsorption capacity toward the OH group in benzyl alcohol. These results are consistent with the in situ DRIFT-IR observations (Fig. 7). In addition, the length of O−H bond (1.015 Å) is found to be elongated after adsorbing on Zr-CeO2-Vö, but that (0.978 Å) adsorbed on the ideal CeO2 (111) surface is barely changed. This reveals an effective O−H bond activation on Ce3+−Vö sites, accelerating the rate-determining step. In addition, some kinetic experiments were further conducted for a better understanding of the reaction path. Oxidative coupling of aniline and benzyl alcohol is a fast-responsive reaction (r initial: 1.52 mmol gcatal. −1 h−1) over the CeZr1O y catalyst (Fig. 8 a). Conversion of aniline reaches 97% after 8 h. But aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol without aniline undergoes a slower course (r initial: 1.02 mmol gcatal. −1 h−1), needing 14 h to attain 97% conversion. Notably, aniline alone cannot be oxidized over the CeZr1O y catalyst. As shown in Fig. 8b, c, the condensation of benzaldehyde with aniline proceeds very fast and 100% yield of imine can be attained after only 1 h. Notably, almost the same time-course data are recorded, which are independent of the catalysts and reaction atmospheres. Hence this condensation reaction is verified as a non-catalytic step. A very high r initial of 25.2 mmol gcatal. −1 h−1 is measured for condensation step, which is over 25 folds to that of aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol over the optimal CeZr1O y catalyst. Moreover, the first-order kinetic profiles can be also plotted for 1) oxidation of benzyl alcohol, 2) oxidative coupling of aniline and benzyl alcohol, and 3) condensation of aniline with benzaldehyde (Fig. 8d). The ratio of k (oxidation step) to k (condensation step) is ca. 2.7 × 10−2. These kinetic results clearly confirm the aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde as the rate-limiting step. Aniline as a weak alkali could facilitate oxidative dehydrogenation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde. The presence of aniline allows promoting the overall reaction by accelerating conversion rate of benzyl alcohol, because the produced benzaldehyde is immediately condensed with aniline to yield an imine, avoiding benzoic acid formation by overoxidation. Hence, oxidative coupling step promotes a fast imine productivity with high atomic utilization and excellent selectivity. Thereafter, a plausible reaction mechanism was discussed. Scheme S2 illustrates the catalytic oxidative coupling of aniline and benzyl alcohol on the interface of a Zr-doped CeO2 solid solution. The coordinatively unsaturated Ce3+−Vö defects are shown as catalytic active sites (Fig. 5) [12]. As for the proposed mechanism, dissociative adsorption of benzyl alcohol on a metal site like Ce3+ to form the alkoxide intermediate was thought as the first step of oxidative coupling [43,44]. This step has been directly observed in this work by in situ DRIFT-IR spectra (Fig. 7). DFT calculations illustrate enhanced adsorption and activation of O−H bond in benzyl alcohol at a Ce3+−Vö site of the CeZr1O y catalyst through favored energy. In the meantime, an O2 molecule can adsorb on Vö and immediately get activated to generate Osurf. species (O2 − and O− ions) [12,41]. The role of oxygen defects in the catalytic cycle has been investigated in this work that a high concentration of defective Osurf. species already exist on the CeZr1O y catalyst, and such reactive species can be continuously supplemented on Vö by adsorbing and activating free O2 (Fig. 4). DFT calculations clearly disclose that defect Vö sites on the (111) plane of a Zr-CeO2-Vö unit can effectively adsorb O2 molecules with a much lowered E ads. (vs. CeO2 alone, Fig. S6), and the O−O bond is observed to be elongated and activated with formation of defective Osurf. species. The highly reactive Osurf. species as electrophilic radicals enable oxidative dehydrogenation of the alkoxide to benzaldehyde and water along with reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+, in agreement with other CeO2 catalytic systems [10,12]. This step is demonstrated as the rate-determining step. Then aniline as nucleophile adds to the generated benzaldehyde to form benzylideneaniline and water [43]. This process is also observed by in situ DRIFT-IR spectra (Fig. 6) and is verified as a very fast and non-catalytic step (Fig. 8). Finally, the imine molecule desorbs from the catalyst surface accompanying oxidation of Ce3+ to Ce4+ by O2 to regenerate catalytic active sites, closing the catalytic cycle. Finally, the efficiency comparison, reusability and substrate scope were studied for the optimal CeZr1O y catalyst. As displayed in Table S4 − S6 and Fig. S9, S10, this catalyst shows some superior performances (see detailed results in the Supplementary material). 4 Conclusions This work reported a Zr-doped CeO2 solid solution catalyst and unraveled its defect chemistry for synthesizing bio-based imine via oxidative coupling of lignin-based aniline and benzyl alcohol. It was demonstrated that the isomorphic substitution of Ce4+ ions by Zr4+ ions inside a cubic CeO2 lattice brought about crystal shrinkage and structure defects. Strong electronic interaction was found between Ce and Zr, obviously promoting redox property of the pristine CeO2. Thereby a higher amount of surface Ce3+ cations, O2 −/O− anions and Vö was induced. The coordinatively unsaturated Ce3+−Vö pairs were shown as the active sites, and the defective Osurf. species (O2 −/O− ions) were critical to selectively converting an alcohol to an aldehyde. This step confirmed as the rate-determining step was observed to happen on the electron-rich Ce3+ sites with a lowered coordination number via formation of an alkoxide intermediate. DFT calculations confirmed that Ce3+−Vö defect sites on Zr-doped CeO2 can more effectively adsorb benzyl alcohol and O2 molecules with much lower E ads, compared with the bare CeO2. Meanwhile, the C−OH and O−O bonds were found to be activated with formation of defective O2 −/O− ions necessary to dehydrogenate C−OH group to C=O group. Hence the produced aldehyde was immediately condensed with aniline to form imine. Therefore, the optimal CeZr1O y catalyst with the highest proportions of surface Ce3+ ions, Osurf. species and Vö enabled the superior performance of oxidative coupling of amines and alcohols in air. The findings in this work may shed light on designing doped-ceria catalysts for oxidative valorization of biomass under mild conditions. coredata.dc:description: The defect chemistry of doped-ceria is vital but tangled for sustainable conversion of biomass resources. In this work, a group of Zr-doped CeO2 solid solutions were prepared and the defect chemistry in CeZr x O y (0.02 ≤ x ≤ 5) catalyst was elucidated over the oxidative coupling of lignin-based aniline and benzyl alcohol. Varying the Zr molar fraction enabled to successfully adjust the defect sites of catalysts and further influence their catalytic performances. In addition, the optimal CeZr1O y catalyst exhibited a flexible temperature adaptability, wide substrate scope and superior reusability. Various characterizations, kinetic investigations, controlled experiments, DFT calculations and in situ DRIFT-IR technique were used to unravel the roles of Ce3+ and oxygen defects and the reaction mechanism. It was disclosed that Zr-doped defects can obviously increase surface Ce3+ cations, oxygen species (peroxide and superoxide anions) and oxygen vacancies. These coordinatively unsaturated sites were shown to play critical roles in absorbing and activating substrates hence can accelerate the formation rate of bio-based imines.
coredata.dc:title: Unraveling defect chemistry in doped-ceria catalyst for oxidative coupling of lignin-based aniline and benzyl alcohol
